, That I have not er this made answear

r

S
r

, I pray yo
w
impute it to my present
negotiations, and not to any want of my rea-
dinesse otherwise. For I hold my self excee-
dingly indebted unto yo
w
, for yo
r
kindnesse
in them bothe: but I have bin so busied w
t
my publicke propositions, privat co
m
unica-
tions, and w
t
dispatches into
England,
about
this c
o
bersome mater in w
ch
I am imploied
that in good sooth I am as weery of my be-
ing in this place, as yo
w
are of those thwarts
at yo
w
finde in yo
r
government. All my
dealing is nowe w
t
e Generallitie, and
M
r
Gilpin
alone appeereth in Councel, of
whose affection unto yo
w
; I could wishe
yo
w
had c
o
ceaved some frindlier opini
o
,
then yo
w
seemed to insinuat by yo
r
last
l
re
to him. For I have founde him heereto-
fore, and so I am assured yo
w
may finde
him heereafter, if yo
w
please to account up
o
him, very forward and willing to serve
yo
r
turne in any thing. Heere are some
of
e
Councel of Estate
at
e Hage, but they
assemble very seeldome, and they doe not
undertake to determine any causes in forme
of a Councel: expecting
e returne of their
collegues at
e Campe, w
ch
I suppose wilbe shortly
fol.129v
Assure yo
r
self
e while,
at I will deale [.]
effectually, assoone as
ei returne,
at the[.]
ters of yo
rs
, may be wholy referred to
e [Coun-]
cel of Zeland: as in truth it were
e [.]
aswell for them, as for yo
r
self, sith they [.]
other maters, as farre as I can c
o
jecture, [.]
were long agoe c
o
plained of, and therfor[e .]
ter knowe to those of Zeland, then to the[.]
heere. Mons
r
Alleman
e Councello[r]
of
Zeland
doth incline already to
at co[.]
and as I should suppose, it
ceedeth of so[.]
king,
at he findeth in so others,
at wri[.]
him out of Zeland. The examinat[ion]
yo
w

t

r

s unto me, M
r

e Councellors heere: an[.]
wise yo
r
demaundes for men and for [provi-]
sions to finishe yo
r
water workes. I [.]
thinke they will not presse yo
w
to take of [.]
Dutche, to supplie
e wantes of yo
r
g[.]
and if they should, I doe not doubt, bu[t .]
shall by some meanes, cause them to su[.]
for
at it is not c
o
venient for many re[.]
They have, as they say, taken order a[.]
w
t
e
general states
, for yo
r
sea bankes, [.]
sluces: but yo
r
moti
o
for
e souldiers to [.]
in winter better lodged, must attend
e re-
turne of
e Councel of Estate. We have
newes at this instant
at troubleth us all,
That
Count Philip
go ing fourth w
t
500 horse, to
charge 3 Cornets of
e Enemie, in lieu of
3 was encountred w
t
14 (because
e Enemie
fol.130r
before had notice of his coming by some secret
spiall) but yet
e c
o
flict was maintained
very valiantly by o
rs
, who returned againe
w
t
e losse but of 40 souldiers and 70 horse,
for w
ch
they caried w
t
them 16 prisoners,
and 50 horse of
e Enemie, and slewe by
supposal above a hundred. Co. Philip
himself was very soare wounded and taken
prisoner, w
t
his yongue brother Ernest, and
e
Count Ernest of Solmes
a very valiant
yongue gentlem
a
, who is also grievously hurt.
Cap
t
Robert Vere

r
Francis
brother was
slaine in
e place.
